history.text: Hello there :)
Hello! Have you heard of the movie Bruce Almighty?
So what is the name of the new movie
Bruce Almighty! Have you heard of it?
Haven't heard of that one.  How good is it, would you suggest I check it out?
Apparently it has Jim Carrey in it.
Which, if you love comedy, yes!
sounds like something similar to Batman, is it
I absolutely adore comedy
I'm not sure if it is similar to Batman.
what's the main theme, or plot of the movie,
Bruce Wayne, of course, is how I came that conclusion?  Though Carrey is one of my favs

So Jim Carrey plays as the main character, named Bruce. And is working for a tv station but wants to be the main news anchorman. He goes on this journey in search of his goal, while engaging with... guess
MORGAN FREEMAN!!!!!! He plays as the God character.
Also Bruce (Carrey) has a girlfriend named Grace played by Jennifer Aniston.
Freeman, as a God character, way funny!!!
Right??
The movie was made in 2003.
Love Jenn Aniston, anything she is in, has to be a hit
So a bit of an old movie.
oh, okay, now why would Carrey need the God figure?
there's nothing pertaining to death, or immortality, or life after death, is it?
Bruce finds out he somehow has powers, and eventually hears voices, and the voice turns into... God!
lol!
Who explains that the voices are people's prayers TO God
how touching....
Bruce is pretty annoyed by the voice of God, but God tells him he needs help.
And nope, nothing with death that I see...
sounds like it has a spiritual flare, or theme to it, then someone who is highly religious, or spiritual would get a kick out of this one, you think?
God shows up to tell Bruce, who is suffering relationship issues with Grace aka Aniston, to pray for what he wants, since Bruce ends up going through a tale/journey of funny woes
It does touch on religion. That would be subjective!
Bruce has been having relationship issues with his girlfriend, who God helps with
And they eventually become married.
So if you like sappy, comedy movies, this is that!
oh I see.  How about Aniston, is who supportive to Bruce goals?
They become engaged, so it can be implied. But you would have to watch the movie!
how does Jenn Aniston react to Bruce's dilemna?
Engaged, that's exciting, and a nice twist, or turn of events
No word on her opinion. The plot is more about Bruce and God.
But,
it's primarily an adult movie, it sounds like. What age group would it cater to, like , how young and audience?

after the journey of having to deal with hearing all the voices "prayers" and Bruce having to figure out how to deal with those, which is figured out in the movie, and after the engagement. The film ends with a man whom is homeless...
who is shown in the beginning of the movie apparently
who holds a sign with philosophical messages that Bruce had seen,
and at the end of the movie, the homeless guy shows himself as the God. Aka, MORGAN FREEMAN
oh I see, once again, a nice turn of events
The movie got a CinemaScore of A. No rating shown to me!
how ironic, that the homeless guy is actually God
Age wise.
still from your depiction, it sounds like a movie I would definitely want to check out
That's a positive thing, it sounds like!
especially with an A rating
...indeed it is!
I've got the gist of it now. Unless there is something more that you think I should be aware of, then I believe we can finish up our conversation, you agree?
The weird thing in the movie, to me, is how the movie starts with him just trying to get a job promotion... but ends up meeting God.....
Lisa Ann Walter and Philip Baker Hall are also main characters in the movie
oh, okay, that is a bit weird, you're right
another set of superb actors and actresses
Someone left a critical response review claiming "one of Jim Carrey's best films"
So it sounds good!
In my opinion.
And according to the movie.
I'm impressed, and am sold by your review and opinions, actually. And will def make it a point to check this one out.

uid1response.feedback: Definitely a movie, that based on the review I just obtained, I would be interested in checking this one out.
